assigmentName: Referring to Research in Academic Discussions

stems:
Verified data and statistics
Databases (such as Statista or IBIS World)
General_information_websites_(such_as_Wikipedia)
Company websites (for factual information)
Government websites
Entertainment websites 
Educational websites (such as universities) 
Social media
Published books
Academic journals
data.stimulus:
In this lesson, we will focus on...

Using research to support your points of view.

► This is useful for your assignments - both written and spoken.

 

Are the sources below suitable to support academic assignments?

In the following video, Vignesh, a Marketing student at Coventry University London, talks about his experience as an international student.

 

 

Which of the topics below is his MAIN focus?

list:
Being with people who have similar goals
Feeling confident about working internationally
  
Gaining unique business experience
Joining a special student programme
Enjoying a different academic style
Learning about different cultures
Doing an internship
data.stimulus: Watch the video again and organise the topics below in the order they are discussed.

This video is a suitable source to cite as evidence in your seminar. 

► TRUE or FALSE?

options.label: It is not from a reliable website
It is not recent (it's too old)
It is promotional material (may be biased)

data.template: Although the information in the video is {{response}}, it may be {{response}}. Promotional materials will often focus ONLY on {{response}} aspects. However, the video is useful to {{response}} and to use as a {{response}} to your research.

options.label: Many graduates appear to have used the experience of working in the UK to enhance their existing careers
Many graduates believed that they made important contacts because they studied in the UK.
Networking while studying in the UK makes it easier to find jobs abroad.
Although networking is important, more UK international students find work through other methods.
Networking is the most important single factor for UK international. students when finding a job after university
This data shows that international students in the UK have better networks than those who study in their own country.

data.stimulus:
In the video, Vignesh argued that studying in the UK would benefit his career prospects as it provided him with opportunities to network.

► To CHECK this is accurate, you must do further research. 

 

Here are some statistics from a 2019 survey by Universities UK.

► Study the data and answer the questions.

Universities UK. (2020) International Graduate Outcomes 2019. https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/International/Documents/international_graduate_outcomes.pdf.

 

►  Which of the sentences below are supported by this evidence?

(choose FOUR)

Here is some more data.

► Analyse the diagram and complete the DATA ANALYSIS below.

 

UKCISA (2004) International students in UK universities & colleges: broadening our horizons. https://www.ukcisa.org.uk/Research--Policy/Resource-bank/resources/90/Broadening-Our-Horizons-Survey-2004
data.template:
DATA ANALYSIS: 

  • {{response}} of international students had ONLY UK friends. 
  • {{response}} of international students only had friends from their own country.  
  • {{response}} of international students had friends from other countries (but not from their own country or the UK).  
  • {{response}} of international students had friends from all parts of the student community.  
  • {{response}} of international students only had friends from their own community and other non-UK students. 
  • {{response}} of international students had student friends from the UK.  
  • {{response}} of international students had student friends from other countries.

data.stimulus:
Verbal Citations

► In a discussion, you need to clearly refer to your sources verbally.

Here are some examples:

1. According to statistics from the Universities UK 2019 Report on International Graduate Employment Outcomes, using networks was the most common method for international students to find a job.

2. The 2004 UKCISA Report on International Student Experience reports that only 39% of international students in the UK socialise with local students.

 

 

But WHY do you need verbal citations? 

► Complete the below paragraphs with words from the drop down.
data.template:
It is necessary to cite sources in academic {{response}} as well as in written work. We need to do this to {{response}} and show where the ideas come from. 
Citing sources also helps other members of the group. Often students {{response}} they have all read and this allows them to {{response}} on the source and add to the discussion.

When you {{response}} make sure you give enough information for other members of the group to know what you are talking about, for example {{response}}, {{response}} the source discussed and {{response}} wrote it.

data.stimulus:
Below are some examples of evidence from different types of sources.

► Complete the verbal citations by putting the phrases in the correct order.
data.template: 1. {{response}} {{response}} {{response}} {{response}}, it's a good idea to contact local alumni associations.
2. {{response}} {{response}} {{response}} {{response}}, {{response}} the extent of the problem caused by isolation.
3. {{response}} {{response}}, {{response}} {{response}} an internship programme for high performers.
4. {{response}} {{response}}, {{response}} {{response}} the UK was the most popular destination for Thai students studying abroad.

data.stimulus:
In the final part of today's lesson, we will focus on Discussion Language.

► During a discussion, it can be hard to find the right moment to make your point.

 

 

Here are some useful phrases you can use when you want to enter the discussion. 

► Choose the missing words to complete each phrase.
data.template:
To enter the discussion politely but firmly:

  • Can I just {{response}} in here?
  • Can I {{response}}…?
  • Sorry, just one {{response}} thing…

If the discussion moves on, you can make your point later:

  • {{response}} to what John said earlier, …
  • I think I agree with the point you made {{response}}, Anne.
  • To {{response}} to my earlier point, …

If you try to speak at the same time as someone else, it is polite to offer the chance to continue:

  • {{response}}, please go on.
  • Please, {{response}}.
  • Sorry, you {{response}} to say…

To invite a quiet student to participate:

  • I think Mike {{response}} to make a point.
  • David, did you want {{response}}?
  • Luke, {{response}} to add something?
